unnormalised: Organic Farming: Back to Our Roots, Yaar!
normalised: Organic Farming: Back to Our Roots, Yaar!

unnormalised: Hey Kisan friends! Tired of seeing your baingan looking sad and your soil turning to dust? Maybe it's time to ditch the chemical funda and embrace organic farming. It's like going back to basics, just like our grandfathers used to do in the villages.
normalised: Hey Kisan friends! Tired of seeing your baingan looking sad and your soil turning to dust? Maybe it is time to ditch the chemical funda and embrace organic farming. It is like going back to basics, just like our grandfathers used to do in the villages.

unnormalised: Organic farming, simply put, means growing crops and raising animals without using synthetic pesticides, fertilizers, or genetically modified organisms (GMOs). Think good old cow dung instead of urea, and natural pest control instead of those nasty chemicals that Dr. Sharma keeps pushing. It's all about working with nature, not against it.
normalised: Organic farming, simply put, means growing crops and raising animals without using synthetic pesticides, fertilizers, or genetically modified organisms (G M O S). Think good old cow dung instead of urea, and natural pest control instead of those nasty chemicals that Doctor Sharma keeps pushing. It is all about working with nature, not against it.

unnormalised: Now, I know what you're thinking: "Will I even make any paisa?" Of course, you will! Initially, the yields might be a little lower, but the quality is top-notch. Plus, organic produce fetches a better price in the market. People in Delhi and Mumbai are willing to pay a premium for chemical-free veggies. Even apna beta, Rohan, who works in IT, insists on organic these days. He says it's better for his health. And hey, healthier crops also mean healthier soil in the long run, setting you up for generations of good harvests.

unnormalised: There are so many cool techniques to explore! Crop rotation, for example, helps keep the soil fertile naturally. Companion planting – like growing marigolds next to your tomatoes – can keep pests away. Vermicomposting using earthworms is like magic for the soil; even better than the jadoo of Koi Mil Gaya!

unnormalised: Don't think it's all just philosophy though. The National Centre of Organic Farming (NCOF) in Ghaziabad provides training and resources. Many Krishi Vigyan Kendras (KVKs) in states like Maharashtra and Punjab also run workshops on organic farming practices. They can even advise you on getting certified as an organic farm, which opens up access to bigger markets and better prices.

unnormalised: Starting small is the key. Maybe dedicate a small plot of land – say 500 sq ft – to try out organic methods. Experiment, learn, and adapt. Talk to other organic farmers in your area. Share tips and tricks. It’s a community effort!
